statement:
$G \subset {\mathbb{C}}^n$ is pseudoconvex if and only if for any family
of closed analytic discs $\{ d_{\alpha} \}_{\alpha \in I}$ in $G$ with
$\cup_{\alpha \in I} \partial d_\alpha$ being a relatively compact set
in $G$ then $\cup_{\alpha \in I} d_\alpha$ is also a relatively compact
set in $G$.

This is the analogue of one of the definitions of a convex set. Just
replace pseudoconvex with convex and closed analytic discs with closed
line segments.
